title-part.text: CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION TECHNOLOGIES IN INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATION TECHNOLOGIES [ICT], I.E. INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATION TECHNOLOGIES AIMING AT THE REDUCTION OF THIR OWN ENERGY USE

note.note-paragraph: This subclass covers information and communication technologies [ICT] whose purpose is to minimize the use of energy during the operation of the involved ICT equipment.
This subclass does not cover the use of an ICT technology supporting energy efficient operation of a further piece of equipment, nor the reuse or recycling of ICT equipment.

title-part.text: Energy efficient computing
Reducing energy consumption at the single machine level, e.g. processors, personal computers, peripherals or power supply
involving a plurality of components
acting upon the main processing unit
Low-power processors
Performance modes
Frequency modification
Clock disabling
Access, addressing or allocation within memory systems or architectures, e.g. to reduce power consumption or heat production or to increase battery life
Interconnection, or transfer of information or other signals between, memories, peripherals or central processing units
acting upon peripherals
the peripheral being a bus
the peripheral being a memory control unit [MCU]
the peripheral being a display
the peripheral being disc or storage devices
the peripheral being a CD-ROM unit
the peripheral being a cursor control device
the peripheral being a keyboard
the peripheral being a modem
the peripheral being a PCMCIA card
the peripheral being a printer
Data transfer to print units
Cooling means for computing equipment provided with thermal management
Power management
Selective power distribution
Controlling the supply voltage
Monitoring user presence
Battery monitoring
Power strips aiming to energy efficient operation
Reducing energy consumption by means of multiprocessor or multiprocessing based techniques, other than acting upon the power supply
Resource allocation
Scheduling
Increasing resource utilisation, e.g. virtualisation, consolidation
Load distribution
Reducing energy consumption in distributed systems
Delegation or migration
Monitoring
Resource sharing
Reducing energy consumption at software or application level
Compilation
Installation
At application level, i.e. feedback, prediction or usage patterns
Suspending or hibernating, performance or eco-modes, operating system support, e.g. advanced configuration and power interface [ACPI]
Information retrieval in databases
High level techniques for reducing energy consumption in communication networks
by proxying, i.e. delegating network functionalities while in low-power mode, e.g. ECMA 393 standard
by energy-aware routing
by signaling and coordination, e.g. signaling reduction, link layer discovery protocol [LLDP], control policies, green TCP
specifically suitable for Ethernet, e.g. IEEE802.3az
specifically suitable for DSL
Application modification for reducing energy consumption, e.g. green peer-to-peer,
Techniques for reducing energy consumption in wire-line communication networks
using reduced link rate, e.g. adaptive link rate, not involving auto-negotiation
using subset functionality
by selective link activation in bundled links
by operating in low-power or sleep mode
specifically suitable for Ethernet, e.g. IEEE802.3az
specifically suitable for DSL
Techniques for reducing energy consumption in wireless communication networks
according to the Radio Access Technology [RAT]
in 3rd Generation Partnership Project [3GPP] networks
in 2nd generation [2G] networks
in Global System for Mobile Communications [GSM] networks
in General Packet Radio Service [GPRS] networks
in Enhanced Data rates for GSM Evolution [EDGE] networks
in 3rd generation [3G] networks
in Universal Mobile Telecommunications Systems [UMTS] networks
in High-Speed Downlink Packet Access [HSDPA] networks
in High-Speed Uplink Packet Access [HSUPA] networks
in 4th generation [4G] networks
in Long-Term Evolution [LTE] networks
in Long-Term Evolution Advanced [LTE-A] networks
in Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers [IEEE] networks
in Wireless Local Area Networks [WLAN]
in Bluetooth and Wireless Personal Area Networks [WPAN]
in Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access [WiMAX] networks
in other wireless communication networks
in Zigbee networks
in Satellite Navigation receivers
in Radio Frequency Identification [RF-ID] transceivers
in Digital Video Broadcasting [DVB] networks
independent of Radio Access Technologies
in machine-to-machine [M2M] and device-to-device [D2D] communications
in peer-to-peer [P2P], ad hoc and mesh networks
in Voice over IP [VoIP] networks
in Discontinuous Reception [DRX] networks
in Discontinuous Transmission [DTX] networks
in wearable devices, e.g. watches, glasses
Power-based selection of communication route or path
based on wireless node resources
based on characteristics of available antennas
based on transmission power
based on available power or energy
based on transmission quality or channel quality
based on geographic position or location
using selective relaying for reaching a BTS [Base Transceiver Station] or an access point
According to the transmission technology
Near-field transmission systems, e.g. inductive or capacitive coupling
Radio transmission systems, i.e. using radiation field
Diversity systems
Multi-antenna systems, i.e. transmission or reception using multiple antennas
using two or more spaced independent antennas
Relay systems
for communication between two or more posts
at least one of which is mobile
Transmission systems employing electromagnetic waves other than radio-waves, e.g. infrared, visible or ultraviolet light, or employing corpuscular radiation, e.g. quantum communication
Transmission systems employing sonic, ultrasonic or infrasonic waves
